description: Ensures select element has an accessible name
help: Select element must have an accessible name
html: [['<select id="CountryCode" name="CountryCode" required="" field="">']]
failureSummary: [['Fix all of the following:\n  Form element has explicit <label> that is hidden']]
prompts_baseline_one: Given the following source code "<select id="CountryCode" name="CountryCode" required="" field="">", can you fix the accessibility issue related to the success criteria: ( Select element must have an accessible name ) according to WCAG 2.1?
responses_baseline_one:
Absolutely, to address the accessibility issue in the given source code relating to the requirement that select elements must have an accessible name according to WCAG 2.1, you need to ensure that the `<select>` element is properly labeled. One common method to achieve this is by using the `<label>` element. 

Here's how you can fix the code:

```html
<label for="CountryCode">Country:</label>
<select id="CountryCode" name="CountryCode" required="">
  <option value="">--Please choose a country--</option>
  <!-- Add country options here -->
</select>
```

In this fixed version, a `<label>` element with the text "Country:" is associated with the `<select>` element through the use of the `for` attribute, which matches the `id` of the `<select>`. This ensures that the select element has an accessible name, as the label clearly describes its purpose. Now, users, especially those using assistive technologies, will understand what is being asked without needing to infer from context or other less reliable methods. 

Remember, accessibility improvements like this are crucial for ensuring that your web content is usable by everyone, including people with disabilities.

prompts_baseline_one: Given the following source code " Calendar Interop tool", can you fix the accessibility issue related to the success criteria: ( Links must be distinguishable without relying on color ) according to WCAG 2.1?
responses_baseline_one: Certainly. To fulfill the WCAG 2.1 guidelines regarding making links distinguishable without relying solely on color, we can enhance the link accessibility by providing additional cues. These can be in the form of underlines (which is traditional and widely recognized), unique symbols, or adding descriptive text. For clarity and to focus on web standards, I'll add underlines (assuming the CSS doesn't already do this) and also include more descriptive text inside the links, making it clear where the links lead without needing to hover or focus on them, which can be particularly helpful for screen reader users. Here is how you can improve the given source code for better accessibility: ```html Learn how to migrate your organization’s data to Google Workspace Discover the Calendar Interop tool ``` Here are the key improvements made: 1. **Text Decoration:** Added `style="text-decoration: underline;"` to ensure links are underlined, making them visually distinguishable from non-link text without relying on color. While CSS is generally the preferred method for styling (for maintainability and performance), inline styles are used here for demonstration purposes. 2. **Descriptive Link Text:** Updated the anchor text to more descriptive phrases. This not only helps with accessibility but also improves the user experience by making it clear what users can expect when they click on the link. 3. **Aria-Label:** Although the text is now descriptive, adding `aria-label` provides an additional layer of clarity, particularly for users relying on screen readers. This label offers an opportunity to give a slightly more detailed description of the link destination if necessary. Remember, this approach assumes that underlining links is the chosen method to distinguish them, which is common but not universal. The main goal is to ensure that links are visually distinct through means other than color alone, as per WCAG 2.1 guidelines. Always test with your target audience and consider multiple aspects of accessibility and user experience in your design decisions.

description: Landmarks should have a unique role or role/label/title (i.e. accessible name) combination
help: Ensures landmarks are unique
html: [['<aside class="container  tooltip-below ">']]
failureSummary: [['Fix any of the following:\n  The landmark must have a unique aria-label, aria-labelledby, or title to make landmarks distinguishable']]
prompts_baseline_one: Given the following source code "<aside class="container  tooltip-below ">", can you fix the accessibility issue related to the success criteria: ( Ensures landmarks are unique ) according to WCAG 2.1?
responses_baseline_one:
The source code snippet you've provided is:

```html
<aside class="container tooltip-below">
```

This snippet indicates the use of an `<aside>` element, which typically represents a section of a page that consists of content indirectly related to the document's main content. According to the Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG) 2.1, a key principle for accessibility is ensuring that landmarks are unique when more than one landmark of a given type is present on a page. Landmarks are regions of the page identified with WAI-ARIA (Web Accessibility Initiative - Accessible Rich Internet Applications) roles or HTML5 semantic tags (like `<aside>`, `<nav>`, `<header>`, and so on), which help users understand page structure and navigate more easily, especially those using assistive technologies.

To fix an accessibility issue related to ensuring landmarks are unique, it's important to ensure that each landmark that appears more than once on a page is distinguishable from others. For `<aside>` elements or other landmarks, this can usually be achieved using the `aria-label` or `aria-labelledby` attributes to provide unique labels for each.

For example, if your webpage contains multiple `<aside>` elements used for different purposes, you should label them accordingly:

```html
<aside class="container tooltip-below" aria-label="Helpful Tips">
  <!-- Content for helpful tips -->
</aside>

<aside class="container tooltip-below" aria-label="Sidebar Navigation">
  <!-- Content for sidebar navigation -->
</aside>
```

By doing this, users of assistive technologies can distinguish between the different `<aside>` sections, enhancing the page's accessibility. If your situation does not involve multiple `<aside>` elements but is about ensuring that landmarks are unique and properly labeled when necessary, the principle remains the same: use appropriate labeling to distinguish content sections.

If you have multiple landmarks of the same type (not just `<aside>` elements, but also `<nav>`, `<footer>`, `<header>`, etc.), make sure each is uniquely identifiable. Always consider the content and context of the landmark when assigning an `aria-label` to ensure it provides meaningful information to users.

description: Ensures the document has a main landmark
help: Document should have one main landmark
html: [['<html lang="en" data-cb-input-m="initial" data-cb-intent-m="initial" style="display: block;">']]
failureSummary: [['Fix all of the following:\n  Document does not have a main landmark']]
prompts_baseline_one: Given the following source code "<html lang="en" data-cb-input-m="initial" data-cb-intent-m="initial" style="display: block;">", can you fix the accessibility issue related to the success criteria: ( Document should have one main landmark ) according to WCAG 2.1?
responses_baseline_one:
Sure, to adhere to WCAG 2.1 guidelines and ensure there's one main landmark in your HTML document, you can fix the given source code by explicitly indicating a main content area using the `<main>` tag. This tag defines the main content of the document and is a way to meet the accessibility requirement for having one main landmark. Here's how to adjust your source code:

```html
<html lang="en" data-cb-input-m="initial" data-cb-intent-m="initial" style="display: block;">
<head>
    <title>Your Page Title</title>
</head>
<body>
    <!-- Your site's Navigation, Header, Sidebar, or other content goes here -->

    <!-- Start of main content area -->
    <main role="main">
        <!-- Your main content goes here -->
    </main>
    <!-- End of main content area -->

    <!-- Your site's Footer or other content goes after -->
</body>
</html>
```

- **`<main>` Element**: Adding a `<main>` tag around your central content effectively communicates to assistive technologies, like screen readers, where the main content begins. This allows users to quickly navigate to or skip over the primary content of the page. 

- **`role="main"` Attribute**: While the `<main>` element implicitly indicates a document's main content area, explicitly declaring `role="main"` ensures compatibility with older assistive technologies and Internet Explorer.

Remember, it’s essential to have only one `<main>` landmark in a document to avoid confusion about where the primary content is located. This does not restrict you from having sections or articles within the `<main>` element, but the main landmark itself should be singular.

prompts_baseline_one:
Given the following source code "<video title="Team discussing work in the Slack app" role="img" data-js-id="hero" loop="" muted="" playsinline="" poster="https://a.slack-edge.com/2951054/marketing/img/homepage/e2e-prospects/animations/static/hero-product-ui.jpg">
<video title="A connected team discussing work in multiple channels in the Slack app" role="img" data-js-id="connectedness" loop="" muted="" playsinline="">
<video data-js-id="flexibility" title="A user starting a huddle and recording a video clip the Slack app" role="img" loop="" muted="" playsinline="">
<video data-js-id="speed" title="Using the Workday integration to quickly file an expense report in the Slack app" role="img" loop="" muted="" playsinline="">", can you fix the accessibility issue related to the success criteria: ( ARIA role should be appropriate for the element ) according to WCAG 2.1?
responses_baseline_one:
To address the accessibility issue mentioned, it's important to make sure that the ARIA role assigned to each element is appropriate, according to WCAG 2.1 guidelines. In the provided code, the `<video>` elements are assigned the role `img`, which might not be the most appropriate due to the dynamic nature of videos, even if they are meant to be purely decorative or illustrative in this context.

The ARIA role `img` is intended for images, and while it can be used to indicate that an element (or a set of elements) should be treated as a single image, using it for a video might not accurately convey the element's nature to assistive technologies. For videos that are meant to convey information (even if they are not intended for direct interaction), no ARIA role might be needed, as the `<video>` tag itself is sufficiently semantic. However, if the intention is really to treat these videos as purely decorative and to prevent screen readers from reading out their titles or interacting with them as videos, one approach could be to ensure that they are indeed perceived as decorative content without misleading user agent about their true nature.

Here's a revised version of the code, removing the `role=img`, which generally improves accessibility compliance regarding the use of ARIA roles:

```html
<video title="Team discussing work in the Slack app" data-js-id="hero" loop="" muted="" playsinline="" poster="https://a.slack-edge.com/2951054/marketing/img/homepage/e2e-prospects/animations/static/hero-product-ui.jpg"></video>
<video title="A connected team discussing work in multiple channels in the Slack app" data-js-id="connectedness" loop="" muted="" playsinline=""></video>
<video data-js-id="flexibility" title="A user starting a huddle and recording a video clip in the Slack app" loop="" muted="" playsinline=""></video>
<video data-js-id="speed" title="Using the Workday integration to quickly file an expense report in the Slack app" loop="" muted="" playsinline=""></video>
```

In case these videos are indeed meant to be interactive (e.g., play/pause upon user interaction) rather than just decorative, it would be better not to alter their semantic meaning through ARIA roles that don't align with their functionality. Instead, ensuring that they are accessible through proper labels, keyboard accessibility, and so forth would be the priority. Always tailor the approach to the specific content and interaction model you're dealing with.

responses_baseline_one:
To adhere to the WCAG 2.1 guidelines, specifically ensuring landmarks are unique where necessary (WCAG 2.4.1 Bypass Blocks), each landmark should either have a unique role or a unique label when multiple landmarks of the same type are present. Since both the `<header>` and `<footer>` elements act as landmarks, if your document contains more than one of either, you should add an `aria-label` or `aria-labelledby` attribute to make them uniquely identifiable. This is particularly important for users relying on assistive technologies.

<header role="banner" aria-label="Main Header">

</footer>
```

In this correction:

- I've added the `aria-label` attribute to both the `<header>` and `<footer>` elements. This attribute provides each landmark with a unique name.
  
- For the `<header>`, I've used the label "Main Header", and for the `<footer>`, I've used "Main Footer". These labels are examples, and you should choose labels that accurately describe the sections' purposes or contents.

If your webpage contains just one header and one footer, these extra `aria-label` attributes are not strictly necessary for compliance with the unique landmarks requirement. However, if there are indeed multiple landmarks of the same type, these labels will significantly enhance navigation for users of assistive technology.

Remember to adjust the `aria-label` values to reflect the content or function of each landmark region accurately. If you're using `aria-labelledby` instead, ensure the value provided is the `id` of an element that provides a label for the landmark.

responses_baseline_one:
To remedy the accessibility issue in your source code and meet the Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG) 2.1 success criteria regarding the skip link, it's crucial to ensure that the target of the skip link (referenced by the `href` attribute) exists and is focusable. The skip link in your code directs to an element with the ID of "main_focusable". Here's a step-by-step guide to fix the issue: 1. **Ensure Existence of Target Element**: Verify that the destination for the skip link (`#main_focusable`) exists within your HTML document. If it doesn't, you'll need to add an element with that ID. Typically, this would be the main content area. 2. **Make the Target Element Focusable**: For an element to be focusable, especially if it's not inherently focusable (like form inputs or links), you can add a `tabindex` attribute to it. Setting `tabindex="-1"` makes the element programmatically focusable but does not include it in the tab sequence for keyboard users, which is generally what you want for skip link targets. ### Example Solution Assuming the target element doesn't already exist, you would add it around your main content. Also, ensure the element can accept focus by setting `tabindex="-1"` like so: ```html Skip to main content
``` With this fix: - You ensure there's a destination for your skip link that matches the `href` attribute of the link. - By adding `tabindex="-1"` to the target element, you've made it programmatically focusable, allowing screen readers and keyboard users to skip to the main content more efficiently. This solution addresses the WCAG 2.1 success criteria related to providing mechanisms to bypass blocks of content (2.4.1 Bypass Blocks) by ensuring the skip link functions as expected, enhancing the accessibility and usability of the website for keyboard and screen reader users.

description: Ensures <meta name="viewport"> does not disable text scaling and zooming
help: Zooming and scaling must not be disabled
html: [['<meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width,minimum-scale=1,maximum-scale=1,user-scalable=no">']]
failureSummary: [['Fix any of the following:\n  user-scalable=no on <meta> tag disables zooming on mobile devices']]
prompts_baseline_one: Given the following source code "<meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width,minimum-scale=1,maximum-scale=1,user-scalable=no">", can you fix the accessibility issue related to the success criteria: ( Zooming and scaling must not be disabled ) according to WCAG 2.1?
responses_baseline_one:
Yes, the provided meta tag disables zooming and scaling on mobile devices, which is an accessibility issue as it prevents users with low vision from scaling content to make it more readable. According to the Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG) 2.1, success criterion 1.4.4 Resize text and 1.4.10 Reflow, users should be able to resize text up to 200 percent without the use of assistive technology and content should reflow in a single column at that zoom level. Disabling zooming and scaling contradicts these requirements.

To fix the issue while adhering to WCAG 2.1, you should modify the meta tag to allow for zooming and scaling. Here's an updated version of your meta tag:

```html
<meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1">
```

This revised meta tag sets the width of the viewport to the width of the device to ensure that the layout is optimized for mobile screens, and it sets the initial scale of the page to 1 (100 percent). Most importantly, it does not include restrictions on minimum-scale, maximum-scale, or user-scalable=no, allowing users to zoom and scale the page content as needed for accessibility.

responses_baseline_one:
Certainly! To address the accessibility issue identified by the success criteria that elements should not have tabindex greater than zero, according to WCAG 2.1, we need to remove or adjust the `tabindex` values for each input element to ensure they are either set to "0" (which means that the element should be focusable in a way that follows the sequential order defined by the document's structure) or completely remove it to let the browser manage focus order based on the document's source order.

```

Here are the changes made:
- Removed all `tabindex` attributes. This ensures that the tab order follows the document's structure, which is a more natural navigation method that benefits all users, not just those relying on assistive technologies. Any explicit `tabindex` greater than 0 has been removed to adhere to the guidelines.
- Kept all other attributes as they are, assuming they meet other accessibility guidelines (e.g., `aria-required` for indicating required fields).

prompts_baseline_one: Given the following source code "<select class="sc-1x8wc7t-0 bBrjxy"><option value="en">English</option><option value="es">Español</option><option value="de-DE">Deutsch</option><option value="fr-FR">Français</option><option value="ja-JP">日本語</option><option value="pt-BR">Português</option><option value="ko-KR">한국어</option></select>", can you fix the accessibility issue related to the success criteria: ( Select element must have an accessible name ) according to WCAG 2.1?
responses_baseline_one:
To fix the accessibility issue related to the success criteria that a select element must have an accessible name, you should provide a form of descriptive labeling. This can be done in several ways, but the most common approach is to use a `<label>` element or the `aria-label` or `aria-labelledby` attributes. It's crucial for users, especially those using screen readers, to understand what the selection controls are for.

Here's how you can modify the given source code to comply with the WCAG 2.1 guidelines by using a `<label>` element:

```html
<label for="language-select">Choose a language:</label>
<select id="language-select" class="sc-1x8wc7t-0 bBrjxy">
  <option value="en">English</option>
  <option value="es">Español</option>
  <option value="de-DE">Deutsch</option>
  <option value="fr-FR">Français</option>
  <option value="ja-JP">日本語</option>
  <option value="pt-BR">Português</option>
  <option value="ko-KR">한국어</option>
</select>
```

In this modification, I've added a `<label>` element with the text "Choose a language:" before the `<select>` element. The `for` attribute of the label must match the `id` attribute of the `<select>` element. This explicitly associates the label with the select field, making it clear for screen reader users what the selection field is for.

Alternatively, if you prefer not to use a visual label (which could be the case in certain designs), you could use the `aria-label` attribute directly on the `<select>` element like this:

```html
<select id="language-select" class="sc-1x8wc7t-0 bBrjxy" aria-label="Choose a language">
  <option value="en">English</option>
  <option value="es">Español</option>
  <option value="de-DE">Deutsch</option>
  <option value="fr-FR">Français</option>
  <option value="ja-JP">日本語</option>
  <option value="pt-BR">Português</option>
  <option value="ko-KR">한국어</option>
</select>
```

This will also make the select element accessible by giving it an accessible name that screen readers can announce, without adding a visible label element. This might be preferable in user interfaces where space is constrained or where the design aesthetic requires it. However, always consider that a visible label is generally more straightforward for users to understand the context of the form control.

responses_baseline_one:
To comply with the Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG) 2.1 and ensure all page content is contained by landmarks, we should wrap the main content and distinctive sections of the HTML in appropriate landmark roles. These landmarks help assistive technologies navigate the page more efficiently. Common landmark roles include: - `banner` for site-wide header content - `navigation` for navigation links - `main` for the primary content of the page - `complementary` for content related to the main content, but separable from it (e.g., sidebars) - `contentinfo` for footer content - `search` for search form areas - `form` for sections primarily containing a form - `region` with an accessible name provided by `aria-labelledby` or `aria-label` for areas that are not covered by any other landmark role but are still significant enough to warrant a landmark Given the source code, let's implement some landmark roles: ```html

287 million creatives, entrepreneurs, and businesses trust Vimeo

Features

Simple

Quickly create, edit, and share content regardless of your budget or expertise.

How clever people like you put Vimeo to work

``` In this revised code: - I've introduced `header`, `nav`, `main`, `aside`, and `footer` elements which inherently provide landmark roles (except for `main` where I've explicitly set the role for clarity; though `main` by itself should typically suffice). - For content sections that don't fit naturally into these tags but still require segmentation, such as a unique section within `main` or an interactive part of the site, you could use the `section` or `article` tags with `role="region"` accompanied by an `aria-label` or `aria-labelledby` for a descriptive name. Make sure to organize content logically and ensure all interactive elements are accessible, using proper tags and ARIA attributes as needed. This code arrangement should significantly improve accessibility by ensuring that all content is contained within landmarks, aiding users in navigating and understanding the structure of the page more intuitively.

prompts_baseline_one: Given the following source code "<header class="sc-1ekvrxa-2 hKhOLf">", can you fix the accessibility issue related to the success criteria: ( Ensures landmarks are unique ) according to WCAG 2.1?
responses_baseline_one:
To address the accessibility issue related to ensuring landmarks are unique according to WCAG 2.1, you need to ensure that each landmark on the page has a unique role or a unique combination of role and label. This is important so that users, especially those using assistive technologies like screen readers, can distinguish between different areas (landmarks) of the page.

Given your source code snippet: `<header class="sc-1ekvrxa-2 hKhOLf">`, it looks like a `header` landmark is defined. If your page contains multiple elements that could be interpreted as `header` landmarks, you can make each one unique by using the `aria-label` or `aria-labelledby` attribute to provide a unique name for each.

Here's how you could modify the header to include an `aria-label` making it unique:

```html
<header class="sc-1ekvrxa-2 hKhOLf" aria-label="Main Header">
```

Or, if the header is more specific to a section of content (like a section header), naming it accordingly would help:

```html
<header class="sc-1ekvrxa-2 hKhOLf" aria-label="Products Section Header">
```

If you have multiple unique content sections on the page, each with its header, you would adjust the `aria-label` accordingly for each to reflect its content or role within the page structure.

Remember, the choice between `aria-label` and `aria-labelledby` depends on whether you can use a visible label as the landmark's name (`aria-labelledby`) or need to provide an invisible label for assistive technologies (`aria-label`). The goal is to ensure that each landmark is uniquely identifiable, enhancing the website's accessibility for users relying on assistive technologies.

Absolutely, to fix the accessibility issues related to the success criteria, which states that headings should not be empty according to WCAG 2.1, we need to provide meaningful content within each heading tag. Empty headings can confuse users, especially those using screen readers, as they offer no context or information about the following sections of content. Given the source code, I will add generic text to each heading to illustrate how they can be populated with relevant content. In a real-world scenario, these headings would be filled with text appropriate to the content structure and context they are representing. Here's the revised version: ```html

Please adjust the text ("Section Title", "Subsection Title 1", etc.) to fit the actual content of your website or application to ensure the headings are descriptive of the content that follows. This will enhance the user experience, particularly for those relying on assistive technologies to navigate your content.

description: Ensures elements with ARIA roles have all required ARIA attributes
help: Required ARIA attributes must be provided
html: [['<input type="search" autocomplete="off" class="bc-input bc-color-border-focus bc-color-base bc-color-background-base bc-color-border-base" value="" data-initial-value="" id="header-search" placeholder="Find your next great listen" name="keywords" aria-label="Search for an audiobook, newspaper, magazine and more" aria-autocomplete="both" aria-controls="ac-listbox" role="combobox">']]
failureSummary: [['Fix any of the following:\n  Required ARIA attribute not present: aria-expanded']]
prompts_baseline_one: Given the following source code "<input type="search" autocomplete="off" class="bc-input bc-color-border-focus bc-color-base bc-color-background-base bc-color-border-base" value="" data-initial-value="" id="header-search" placeholder="Find your next great listen" name="keywords" aria-label="Search for an audiobook, newspaper, magazine and more" aria-autocomplete="both" aria-controls="ac-listbox" role="combobox">", can you fix the accessibility issue related to the success criteria: ( Required ARIA attributes must be provided ) according to WCAG 2.1?
responses_baseline_one:
Analyzing the provided `<input>` element, it seems to be structured to function as a combobox with suggestions (due to the presence of `role="combobox"` and `aria-controls="ac-listbox"` indicating it controls an element with an id of "ac-listbox" that likely serves as the listbox for autocomplete suggestions). The accessibility issue mentioned refers to the requirement under WCAG 2.1 that elements with certain roles have the required ARIA (Accessible Rich Internet Applications) attributes to support their roles and states adequately for accessibility tools.

For a `role="combobox"` to comply with WCAG 2.1 and ARIA 1.1 specifications, the following attributes are essential:

1. `aria-expanded` to indicate if the combobox is expanded or collapsed.
2. It's also a good practice to ensure that the combobox has associated listbox (`aria-controls="ac-listbox"` is already present which is good).
3. As of ARIA 1.1, a combobox is expected to own a text input and a list, so ensuring there’s a clear relationship between the text input and the list it controls is crucial. This is primarily managed by structuring your HTML and ARIA roles and properties correctly rather than a single attribute fix.

Here's a revised version of your input:

```html
<input type="search" autocomplete="off"
       class="bc-input bc-color-border-focus bc-color-base bc-color-background-base bc-color-border-base"
       value="" data-initial-value=""
       id="header-search"
       placeholder="Find your next great listen"
       name="keywords"
       aria-label="Search for an audiobook, newspaper, magazine and more"
       aria-autocomplete="both"
       aria-controls="ac-listbox"
       aria-expanded="false" <!-- Adjust this with JavaScript based on whether the listbox is displayed or not -->
       role="combobox">
```

With this, you'd need to implement JavaScript logic to update `aria-expanded` to "true" when the user interacts with the combobox and the list of suggestions is displayed, and back to "false" when the list is dismissed or an option is selected.

Remember, the success of accessibility improvements depends not only on adding certain attributes but ensuring that the whole widget's interaction is correctly managed via JavaScript (e.g., focusing, keyboard navigation within the listbox). Implementing proper focus management and keyboard event handling is crucial for making the combobox fully accessible.

description: Ensures elements with an ARIA role that require parent roles are contained by them
help: Certain ARIA roles must be contained by particular parents

prompts_baseline_one:
Given the following source code "<button type="button" data-role="none" role="tab" tabindex="0" id="slick-slide-control00" aria-controls="slick-slide00" aria-label="1 / 5" aria-selected="true">1</button>
<button type="button" data-role="none" role="tab" tabindex="0" id="slick-slide-control10" aria-controls="slick-slide10" aria-label="1 / 5" aria-selected="true">1</button>", can you fix the accessibility issue related to the success criteria: ( Certain ARIA roles must be contained by particular parents ) according to WCAG 2.1?
responses_baseline_one:
Certainly! The issue with the provided source code from an accessibility perspective is that elements with the role of `tab` are expected to be contained within an element with the role of `tablist`. This structure is crucial because it informs assistive technologies that the tab elements are part of a collection of tab controls, which in turn control the visibility of their associated tab panels. To fix the accessibility issue, you need to wrap the ` ``` Here, I've made a few adjustments and notes for clarification and enhancement: 1. **Tablist Container**: I've added a `
` element around the buttons with a `role="tablist"` to specify that these buttons are part of a tab control group. 2. **Correct `aria-label` usage**: The `aria-label` of each button should uniquely describe the tab's purpose or content. For educational purposes, I've made them "1 of 5" and "2 of 5" to reflect their position in the tab order but adjust according to your actual tab contents. 3. **`aria-selected` adjustment**: The `aria-selected` attribute for the second button has been changed to `false`. This indicates that the first tab is selected by default, and the rest are unselected. Make sure this state is managed correctly when a user interacts with the tabs. 4. **Unique Text Labels**: The text inside each button (i.e., the visible label) should be unique and describe the content of the tab panel it controls. For simplicity, I've marked the second button as "2". Ensure that the text labels accurately reflect the content of their respective tab panels. Remember, managing focus and keyboard interaction (e.g., arrow keys to navigate between tabs) is crucial for tabs to be fully accessible. This code snippet addresses the specific WCAG 2.1 criteria you've mentioned, but implementing accessible tabs requires additional behavioral scripting to be fully compliant.

responses_baseline_one:
The provided code snippet indicates that several `<div>` elements share the same class attributes and properties but have unique `id` attributes, which is good for accessibility as each `id` should be unique within a page to maintain the uniqueness criterion for `aria-labelledby`, `aria-describedby`, or any attribute that references the `id`. However, the accessibility issue flagged seems to be the need for ensuring uniqueness not just in `id`s but also in the roles and descriptive labels provided via ARIA (`aria-label` attributes) for assistive technologies.

To address the success criterion "IDs used in ARIA and labels must be unique" according to WCAG 2.1, your `id` attributes are already unique, which is compliant. But if the concern includes the uniqueness of `aria-label` values for elements that serve similar roles (e.g., tooltips for product descriptions), you might need to ensure that each `aria-label` also offers unique descriptive information corresponding to each product. It seems from the code provided, each `aria-label` does indeed contain a unique label (the name of the product), which aligns with the requirement.

However, given the snippet's context, there's no direct violation of the mentioned criterion as the `id`s are unique, and each `aria-label` provides a unique description of its corresponding `div`. If there were issues, they might involve ensuring that every element that requires distinguishing for accessibility purposes, like elements referenced by `aria-labelledby`, is uniquely identifiable not just by `id` but also in the way they are described to users via ARIA attributes.

In summary, as long as each `id` is unique and each `aria-label` or other ARIA attribute providing description or labeling is unique and descriptive of its element, the code meets the WCAG 2.1 criterion for uniqueness.

If there was a specific issue or error reported regarding this, it would be useful to have more details. Based on the provided code and the criterion, the main action would be reviewing each `aria-label` to ensure it uniquely and adequately describes the product or element it's associated with, which seems to have been met based on your snippet.

description: Ensure links are distinguished from surrounding text in a way that does not rely on color
help: Links must be distinguishable without relying on color
html:
[['<a class="bc-link
    
    
    bc-color-link" tabindex="0" href="/search?searchAuthor=Greg+O%27Connor&ref=a_hp_c8_adblp13nmpalp13n-pbs-dt-c_1_1_1&pf_rd_p=997eac75-c975-469e-8d08-d166d5bb8233&pf_rd_r=3NG1TD4W1MC5E77WG580&pageLoadId=J5KtbQHdxmL8JpLh&creativeId=933fe865-0b4b-49bb-abf2-06c37d86cf26">']]
failureSummary: [['Fix any of the following:\n  The link has insufficient color contrast of 2.43:1 with the surrounding text. (Minimum contrast is 3:1, link text: #ffffff, surrounding text: #a6a6a6)\n  The link has no styling (such as underline) to distinguish it from the surrounding text']]
prompts_baseline_one:
Given the following source code "<a class="bc-link
    
    
    bc-color-link" tabindex="0" href="/search?searchAuthor=Greg+O%27Connor&ref=a_hp_c8_adblp13nmpalp13n-pbs-dt-c_1_1_1&pf_rd_p=997eac75-c975-469e-8d08-d166d5bb8233&pf_rd_r=3NG1TD4W1MC5E77WG580&pageLoadId=J5KtbQHdxmL8JpLh&creativeId=933fe865-0b4b-49bb-abf2-06c37d86cf26">", can you fix the accessibility issue related to the success criteria: ( Links must be distinguishable without relying on color ) according to WCAG 2.1?
responses_baseline_one:
To address the accessibility issue indicated—ensuring links are distinguishable without relying solely on color—we need to add more distinguishing features to the link. This can be achieved through various means such as underlining the link, adding an icon, increasing the font weight, or providing additional visual cues that do not depend on color differentiation alone. For web accessibility, underlining is the most common and widely understood cue for indicating links.

Given your source code, I will demonstrate how to fix the issue by adding an underline to the link, which is a straightforward and effective solution. Note that additional strategies can be employed depending on the overall design and user experience strategy of the website.

Original:
```html
<a class="bc-link bc-color-link" tabindex="0" href="/search?searchAuthor=Greg+O%27Connor&ref=a_hp_c8_adblp13nmpalp13n-pbs-dt-c_1_1_1&pf_rd_p=997eac75-c975-469e-8d08-d166d5bb8233&pf_rd_r=3NG1TD4W1MC5E77WG580&pageLoadId=J5KtbQHdxmL8JpLh&creativeId=933fe865-0b4b-49bb-abf2-06c37d86cf26">
```

Fixed for Accessibility:
```html
<a class="bc-link bc-color-link" style="text-decoration: underline;" tabindex="0" href="/search?searchAuthor=Greg+O%27Connor&ref=a_hp_c8_adblp13nmpalp13n-pbs-dt-c_1_1_1&pf_rd_p=997eac75-c975-469e-8d08-d166d5bb8233&pf_rd_r=3NG1TD4W1MC5E77WG580&pageLoadId=J5KtbQHdxmL8JpLh&creativeId=933fe865-0b4b-49bb-abf2-06c37d86cf26">
```

I've added an inline style `style="text-decoration: underline;"` directly to the `<a>` tag to ensure the link is distinguishable by more than color, addressing the WCAG 2.1 guideline for being perceivable to users with color vision deficiencies.

For a more robust solution, especially if you have many links or expect the website's design to evolve, consider adding or modifying the CSS class definitions to include these properties. This will both keep your HTML cleaner and ensure consistency across your site.

Example CSS modification:
```css
.bc-link.bc-color-link {
    text-decoration: underline; /* This ensures links are underlined and more distinguishable */
    /* Add other styles as needed */
}
```

This way, all links using the `bc-link bc-color-link` classes will automatically include an underline, improving accessibility site-wide with a single change.

help: Certain ARIA roles must contain particular children

prompts_baseline_one:
Given the following source code "<ul class="slick-dots slick-dots-inverse" role="tablist" style="">
<ul class="slick-dots slick-dots-inverse" role="tablist" style="">", can you fix the accessibility issue related to the success criteria: ( Certain ARIA roles must contain particular children ) according to WCAG 2.1?
responses_baseline_one:
Yes, I can guide you to address the accessibility issue related to the WCAG 2.1 success criteria regarding certain ARIA roles that must contain particular children. The markup you provided indicates the use of a list (`
    `) classified as "slick-dots slick-dots-inverse", presumably for some form of a slideshow or carousel indicator. However, there are no list items (`
  • `) included within your `
      ` elements, and no roles or ARIA attributes indicating how these should function in terms of accessibility. To address the specific WCAG 2.1 success criterion related to ARIA roles and their required children, you would first ensure that the ARIA role "tablist" is properly used. The role "tablist" is meant to indicate a container for a set of tabs. According to ARIA specifications, a "tablist" role contains children with the role "tab". Here's how you could revise your code to be more accessible, by including proper roles and child elements: ```html
      ``` In this revision: - Each `
    • ` element now plays the presentation role. This role is used to remove the semantic meaning of the list item elements, so they are correctly perceived as part of a control set rather than a list by assistive technologies. The role of each list item itself isn't required to be "presentation", but it's a commonly used method to ensure the list structure does not interfere with the perception of the tab structure. - Each `li` element contains a `button` element with the role "tab". Each button is associated with its respective panel (content that it shows/hides) using `aria-controls`. This is indicated through the `aria-controls` attribute pointing to the ID of the respective panel. - The `aria-selected="true"` attribute indicates which tab is active. Only one tab should be marked as `selected` at a time. - The `id` attribute on each button (`tab1`, `tab2`, etc.) should be unique and could be used to reference the tab from the corresponding panel (not shown in this example) using `aria-labelledby`. As for the `role="tablist"` on the `
        ` element, it is correctly placed. prompts_baseline_one: Given the following source code "<input id="kw" name="wd" class="s_ipt" value="" maxlength="255" autocomplete="off">", can you fix the accessibility issue related to the success criteria: ( Form elements must have labels ) according to WCAG 2.1?
responses_baseline_one:
To address the accessibility issue related to the success criteria "Form elements must have labels" as per WCAG 2.1, we need to ensure that the `<input>` element has a descriptive label associated with it. This improves the accessibility for screen reader users and those with cognitive disabilities by providing context on what information is expected in the input field. There are two common ways to do this:

### 1. Using `<label>` with "for" attribute:
The `for` attribute of the `<label>` tag should match the `id` of the `<input>` element to establish a relationship between the label and the specific input field.

```html
<label for="kw">Search:</label>
<input id="kw" name="wd" class="s_ipt" value="" maxlength="255" autocomplete="off">
```

### 2. Using `aria-label` attribute on `<input>`:
If adding a visible label is not suitable for your design, you can use the `aria-label` attribute directly on the `<input>` tag to provide an accessible name for the accessibility APIs.

```html
<input id="kw" name="wd" class="s_ipt" value="" maxlength="255" autocomplete="off" aria-label="Search">
```

Both methods improve the accessibility of the form element, making it compliant with WCAG 2.1 guidelines. The choice between them depends on the specific needs of your design and whether the label should be visible or not.

---
Given your requirement, I provided two possible fixes for the accessibility issue. Would you like more details about WCAG compliance or assistance with another element?

description: Ensures the document has at most one contentinfo landmark
help: Document should not have more than one contentinfo landmark
html: [['<footer class="footer" id="globalfooter">']]
failureSummary: [['Fix any of the following:\n  Document has more than one contentinfo landmark']]
prompts_baseline_one: Given the following source code "<footer class="footer" id="globalfooter">", can you fix the accessibility issue related to the success criteria: ( Document should not have more than one contentinfo landmark ) according to WCAG 2.1?
responses_baseline_one:
To address the accessibility issue related to the success criterion of having no more than one contentinfo landmark as per WCAG 2.1, it's crucial to ensure that within a single webpage, only one `<footer>` element (or any other element with the semantic role of `contentinfo`) is marked up as such. The `contentinfo` role is typically applied to `footer` elements to denote that they contain information about the parent document, such as copyright information, links to privacy policies, etc.

Given the provided source code snippet:

```html
<footer class="footer" id="globalfooter">
```

Assuming this is the only footer intended to serve as the primary document footer (i.e., the one containing global information about the site), it doesn't inherently have an accessibility issue by itself. However, to address and prevent potential accessibility issues related to the WCAG 2.1 success criterion -- that is, ensuring the document does not have more than one contentinfo landmark -- ensure that:

1. **This is the only footer marked with a role of `contentinfo`** on the page. If there are other `<footer>` elements, they should not also be implicitly or explicitly marked as a `contentinfo` landmark unless they are in different sections of a webpage (e.g., within an `iframe`, `article`, `section`, or other landmark regions where a separate footer might make sense contextually).

2. **Avoid using the `role="contentinfo"` attribute unnecessarily** if you're using HTML5 `<footer>` elements, as it's implicitly assigned this role. If for some reason you have a non-`<footer>` element acting as a footer, you should only assign `role="contentinfo"` to one element in the document.

If the document mistakenly includes more than one element marked up as a contentinfo landmark (either multiple `<footer>` elements intended as the main footer or other elements incorrectly assigned this role), you can fix it as follows:

- **Ensure only the global or main footer has the `<footer>` tag or the `role="contentinfo"`.** Additional footers, which are not meant for global site information but perhaps for subsections of the site, could be marked up differently or use different semantic tags like `<div>`, avoiding role assignment that conflicts with the primary contentinfo landmark.

- **Use semantic HTML correctly** by assigning appropriate roles only when necessary and adhering to the structure that supports accessibility. If designing a complex layout with multiple sections (e.g., a blog with articles each having a footer), structure your documents so that these footers are understood as being part of their respective sections/articles and not as additional global footers.

In summary, without modifications, your source code snippet does not show a direct violation of WCAG 2.1 guidelines concerning having more than one contentinfo landmark. However, checking the overall document structure to ensure compliance is key. If there are multiple contentinfo landmarks, adjust as necessary to meet this criterion by removing or changing the tag/role of additional footers that are not intended as the document's main footer.

description: Landmarks should have a unique role or role/label/title (i.e. accessible name) combination
help: Ensures landmarks are unique
html: [['<footer class="footer" id="globalfooter">']]
failureSummary: [['Fix any of the following:\n  The landmark must have a unique aria-label, aria-labelledby, or title to make landmarks distinguishable']]
prompts_baseline_one: Given the following source code "<footer class="footer" id="globalfooter">", can you fix the accessibility issue related to the success criteria: ( Ensures landmarks are unique ) according to WCAG 2.1?
responses_baseline_one:
To address the accessibility issue related to ensuring landmarks are unique according to WCAG 2.1, particularly when it comes to having multiple landmarks of the same type on a page, you should ensure that each landmark can be distinguished by users of assistive technologies. In HTML5, landmarks are typically defined using elements such as `<header>`, `<nav>`, `<main>`, `<footer>`, etc., and can also be designated using ARIA roles such as `role="banner"`, `role="navigation"`, `role="main"`, `role="contentinfo"`, etc.

Given your source code:

```html
<footer class="footer" id="globalfooter">
```

If your page contains multiple `<footer>` elements or sections that could be considered as landmarks (e.g., footer areas for different sections of the page in addition to the global page footer), you would want to make sure each is unique and identifiable.

### Fixing the Issue

1. **Ensure the `<footer>` is truly a landmark**: The `<footer>` element you've shown is likely intended to be a global footer (given its ID of "globalfooter"). It's important to use `<footer>` elements as landmarks only when they serve a significant role for the entire page or a large section of it. If you have other footer elements, consider if they should all be marked as footer landmarks or if they serve more as content details, in which case a different semantic element or role might be more appropriate.

2. **Use `aria-label` or `aria-labelledby` for unique identification**: To make landmarks unique, you can use the `aria-label` or `aria-labelledby` attributes to provide a unique name for each landmark when the structure of the page results in multiple landmarks of the same type.

    For example, if you have another footer that acts as a section-specific footer in addition to your global footer, you might add:

    ```html
    <!-- Global Footer -->
    <footer class="footer" id="globalfooter" role="contentinfo" aria-label="Global Footer">

    </footer>

    <!-- Section-specific Footer -->
    <footer class="footer" role="contentinfo" aria-label="Section Footer">
    
    </footer>
    ```

    Here, I've added `role="contentinfo"` explicitly, though it's not strictly necessary when using the `<footer>` element correctly in the context of the body or a sectioning content element (like `<article>` or `<section>`). However, adding it might increase clarity for some developers or in complex site structures. The key part is the `aria-label` that differentiates each footer. 

3. **Review and test with screen readers**: After making adjustments, test your page with screen readers like NVDA, JAWS, or VoiceOver to ensure that the landmarks are announced correctly and are distinguishable from each other.

By following these steps, you'll improve the accessibility of your site and comply with WCAG 2.1 requirements regarding ensuring landmarks are unique, making navigation easier for users of assistive technologies.

<aside class="tile--icon">", can you fix the accessibility issue related to the success criteria: ( Aside should not be contained in another landmark ) according to WCAG 2.1?
responses_baseline_one:
Certainly! The original code snippet you provided uses multiple `<aside>` elements, and the concern mentioned relates to the WCAG 2.1 accessibility guidelines. Specifically, this seems to relate to the best practices around the use of HTML5 sectioning elements and how they interact with assistive technologies. While the WCAG 2.1 guidelines directly do not specify that an `<aside>` cannot be contained within another landmark, using many nested sectioning elements, or using them in a way that doesn't convey the true structure of the page, can indeed create confusion for screen readers and users who rely on assistive technologies.

Given your concern, it seems you're aiming to improve the semantic structure of your HTML to make it more accessible by ensuring that these `<aside>` elements are used appropriately—presumably as complementary content outside the main content flow, and not nested within each other or within another landmark without clear purpose.

### Here's how you can address the issue:

1. **Avoid Nesting `<aside>` Elements**: Ensure that `<aside>` elements are not nested within each other, as this could confuse the document structure. Each `<aside>` should be used to mark up content that is related to the surrounding content but could stand independently.

2. **Use Appropriate Landmarks**: If these `<aside>` elements are meant to indicate content that is tangentially related to the main content (such as sidebars, advertisements, or groups of navigation links), then they should not be nested but instead placed appropriately within the global structure of the document.

3. **Ensure Correct Placement**: Place each `<aside>` element in locations where they make semantic sense and where they do not imply an incorrect structure of the document.

Here is an example of how you might structure these elements more appropriately:

```html
<body>
    <main>
        <!-- Your main content goes here -->
    </main>
    <aside class="tile--icon">
        <!-- Content related to the surrounding content, but could stand on its own -->
    </aside>
    <aside class="tile--icon">
        <!-- Another separate aside element -->
    </aside>
    <!-- Additional asides follow the same pattern, not nested and properly placed -->
</body>
```

### Key Takeaways:

- **Do not nest** `<aside>` elements within each other.
- Use `<aside>` to mark up content that is complementary to the main content, ensuring they are placed outside the main content flow but still in a contextually relevant position.
- Review the document's structure to ensure it logically flows and is understandable, not only by sighted users but also by those using assistive technologies.

By following these practices, you'll improve the semantic correctness of your HTML and its accessibility, aligning your work more closely with WCAG 2.1 guidelines.

description: Ensures role attribute has an appropriate value for the element
help: ARIA role should be appropriate for the element
html: [['<select aria-labelledby="global-footer-select-label" class="eds-field-styled__input eds-field-styled__select" role="listbox" id="global-footer-select" name="global-footer-select">']]
failureSummary: [['Fix any of the following:\n  ARIA role listbox is not allowed for given element']]
prompts_baseline_one: Given the following source code "<select aria-labelledby="global-footer-select-label" class="eds-field-styled__input eds-field-styled__select" role="listbox" id="global-footer-select" name="global-footer-select">", can you fix the accessibility issue related to the success criteria: ( ARIA role should be appropriate for the element ) according to WCAG 2.1?
responses_baseline_one:
The source code snippet you provided is using the `<select>` HTML element with an ARIA role of `listbox`. The `<select>` element inherently represents a control that provides a menu of options, and the use of ARIA roles with this element is typically unnecessary as it is already exposed to accessibility APIs in a way that assistive technologies understand. Therefore, adding the `role="listbox"` to the `<select>` element is redundant and might actually create confusion for assistive technologies because it could interfere with the native semantics of the HTML element.

To fix the accessibility issue related to the success criteria stating that the ARIA role should be appropriate for the element, according to WCAG 2.1, you should remove the `role="listbox"` attribute from the `<select>` element. The corrected code would look like this:

```html
<select aria-labelledby="global-footer-select-label" class="eds-field-styled__input eds-field-styled__select" id="global-footer-select" name="global-footer-select">
```

This code removes the redundant ARIA role and relies on the inherent semantics of the `<select>` element, which is more appropriate and accessible according to WCAG 2.1 guidelines. This change ensures that the element's role is correctly interpreted by assistive technologies without unnecessary attributes that could potentially cause confusion or misinterpretation.

responses_baseline_one:
To address the accessibility issue in the provided source code related to WCAG 2.1 criteria for ARIA dialog and alertdialog nodes, it's essential to ensure these nodes have an accessible name. The accessible name helps assistive technologies, like screen readers, to appropriately announce the dialog's purpose to users who rely on such technologies. Given source code: ```html
``` To fix the accessibility issue, ensure that there's an element within the dialog that has the ID referenced by `aria-labelledby` attribute and that this element contains text that serves as the accessible name for the dialog. However, your example code snippet does not show the element with the ID `manage_cookies_title`. Here's how you could adjust the code, along with adding an exemplary element to act as the dialog's label: ```html

Manage Cookies

``` In the adjusted code, a heading (`h2`) element is included with an `id` of `manage_cookies_title`, which matches the value used in `aria-labelledby` attribute of the dialog. The text content of the `h2` element, "Manage Cookies," serves as the accessible name for the dialog. This clearly informs users (through assistive technologies) what the dialog is about when it receives focus. Ensure to replace "Manage Cookies" with a description that accurately reflects the functionality or purpose of your dialog. If the dialog is more of an alert rather than a dialog where the user might interact (e.g., confirm or dismiss), you should use `role="alertdialog"` and apply a similar approach to ensure it has an accessible name. This solution meets the success criteria for ARIA modal dialogues, making your web application more accessible to users who rely on screen readers and other assistive technologies.

description: Ensures <meta name="viewport"> does not disable text scaling and zooming
help: Zooming and scaling must not be disabled
html: [['<meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width,initial-scale=1,maximum-scale=1,user-scalable=no">']]
failureSummary: [['Fix any of the following:\n  user-scalable=no on <meta> tag disables zooming on mobile devices']]
prompts_baseline_one: Given the following source code "<meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width,initial-scale=1,maximum-scale=1,user-scalable=no">", can you fix the accessibility issue related to the success criteria: ( Zooming and scaling must not be disabled ) according to WCAG 2.1?
responses_baseline_one:
Yes, the provided meta tag includes attributes that disable user scaling by setting `user-scalable=no` and restrict maximum scale by `maximum-scale=1`. This can create accessibility issues by preventing users from zooming in or out, which is especially crucial for users with visual impairments who rely on zooming for better readability.

To fix the accessibility issue and comply with the Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG) 2.1 success criteria related to zooming and scaling (which falls under Guideline 1.4 - Make it easier for users to see and hear content), you should allow users to zoom and scale the content.

You would modify the `<meta name="viewport">` tag by removing the `user-scalable=no` and `maximum-scale=1` attributes. The updated meta tag should look like this:

```html
<meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1">
```

This change ensures that users can scale the content up to at least 200%, which is generally considered the minimum requirement for compliance with relevant WCAG success criteria, without explicitly disabling zooming or limiting the scale factor. It's important to note that some browsers and mobile operating systems may ignore these settings, but from a development standpoint, this change is a step towards better accessibility compliance.

description: Ensures the document has a main landmark
help: Document should have one main landmark
html: [['<html lang="en">']]
failureSummary: [['Fix all of the following:\n  Document does not have a main landmark']]
prompts_baseline_one: Given the following source code "<html lang="en">", can you fix the accessibility issue related to the success criteria: ( Document should have one main landmark ) according to WCAG 2.1?
responses_baseline_one:
Certainly! To ensure that the HTML document complies with WCAG 2.1 success criteria regarding having one main landmark, which is essential for screen readers and other assistive technologies to identify the primary content of the page, you'll need to add a `<main>` element to the body of your HTML. This `<main>` element should encapsulate the primary content of your document, making it easier for users to find the main content.

Here is an example of how to fix the provided source code snippet:

```html
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
    <meta charset="UTF-8">
    <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0">
    <title>Document Title</title>
</head>
<body>

    <header>
        <!-- Your header content like navigation, logo, etc. -->
    </header>

    <main>
        <!-- Main content of your document goes here -->
        The primary content of your document.
    </main>

    <footer>
        <!-- Your footer content -->
    </footer>

</body>
</html>
```

In this example:
- **Header**: Marks the top section of your page, typically containing the site's header, navigation links, etc.
- **Main**: This is the key addition that addresses the WCAG 2.1 criteria you're interested in. It should contain the unique content of the page. Note: It is good practice to have only one `<main>` landmark in a page to ensure that the primary content is clear and distinct. This element directly addresses the guideline for having one main landmark.
- **Footer**: Marks the bottom section of your page, typically containing copyright information, contact details, etc.

By structuring your HTML document this way, you ensure that it has a main landmark, improving accessibility according to WCAG 2.1 standards.

An example tool is the WebAIM Contrast Checker. 3. **Adjust Colors for Compliance**: If the current contrast ratio does not meet the minimum requirements, adjust either the text color, the background color, or both until you achieve a compliant contrast ratio. For standard text, aim for a contrast ratio of at least 4.5:1. For larger text, a minimum ratio of 3:1 is needed. 4. **Implement Changes**: Once you have identified compliant color values, incorporate them into your CSS. This might involve inline styles, internal stylesheets, or external stylesheets, depending on how your project is structured. Here is an example demonstrating how you might adjust the code to include color contrast adjustments (assuming a scenario where the contrast needs to be increased): ```html United States ``` In this example, I've assumed default colors that already meet contrast requirements but also provided a commented-out example for a different set of colors—which you would adjust based on your actual color scheme. If there was a label originally associated with this input, its `for` attribute should be updated to match the new `id`. I've also added a `<label>` above for demonstration, with its `for` attribute set to match the `id` of the input. This linkage between the input and its label improves accessibility by making it clear what the input is for, particularly for screen reader users.

Remember, this solution assumes that the label is both visually and programmatically associated with the input. If the label is not intended to be visually displayed (e.g., if you're following a design where labels are not shown), you could either use `aria-label` directly on the input or keep the label and visually hide it in a way that it remains accessible to screen readers.

It's crucial to check the rest of the document to make sure that all `id` values are unique and properly paired with their related elements, whether through `<label>` tags or ARIA attributes (`aria-labelledby` or `aria-describedby`), to fully comply with the WCAG guidelines.

responses_baseline_one: Certainly! The given source code contains anchor (``) tags with only font-awesome icons as their content, which makes it hard for screen readers and other assistive technologies to discern the purpose of the links. According to the Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG) 2.1, under the success criteria of having links with discernible text, we need to ensure that each link has text content that explains its purpose or destination. To fix the accessibility issue and make these links compliant, we can add visually hidden text within the anchor tags that screen readers can announce. This text should clearly describe the purpose or destination of the link. For users who can see the icons but not the hidden text, the user experience remains unchanged. Here is how you can modify the code to meet WCAG 2.1 compliance: ```html Facebook Twitter LinkedIn YouTube Instagram Share via AddThis ``` Here is what was changed: 1. Added `aria-hidden="true"` to the `` tags to hide the icons from screen readers, because they are purely decorative in this context. 2. Introduced `` elements with descriptive text for each link. The class `visually-hidden` is a commonly used utility class that visually hides content but keeps it accessible to screen readers. If your stylesheet doesn't already contain the necessary CSS for `.visually-hidden`, you'll need to include it: ```css .visually-hidden { position: absolute; width: 1px; height: 1px; margin: -1px; padding: 0; overflow: hidden; clip: rect(0,0,0,0); border: 0; } ``` Adding this visually hidden text ensures that the links are now accessible to users relying on assistive technologies, fulfilling the WCAG 2.1 success criteria for having links with discernible text.

Discernible text helps users understand the purpose of the button. Here's how you can fix the source code to meet these requirements:

Option 2: Using the `aria-label` attribute:
```html

<button type="button" data-v-415312cb="" class="" aria-label="Descriptive Name 2"></button>
```
The `aria-label` attribute provides an accessible name for the button when there's no visible text that can be used to convey its purpose. This is useful in instances where adding visible text inside the button would disrupt the design or layout of the page. The value of `aria-label` should clearly describe the button's function, helping screen reader users understand its purpose.

In either case, it's important to provide meaningful descriptions or labels that clearly indicate the function of the button. This makes the content accessible to a wider range of users, including those using screen readers or other assistive technologies.

help: Interactive controls must not be nested

prompts_baseline_one:
Given the following source code "<div role="tab" class="css-jsjvin">
<div role="tab" class="css-jsjvin">
<div role="tab" class="css-jsjvin">
<div role="tab" class="css-jsjvin">", can you fix the accessibility issue related to the success criteria: ( Interactive controls must not be nested ) according to WCAG 2.1?
responses_baseline_one:
To address the accessibility issue related to the success criteria, which is based on WCAG 2.1 guidelines, stating that interactive controls must not be nested, I will refactor the provided source code. The original code snippet you provided has multiple divs with the role of "tab" nested within each other, which is not compliant with the accessibility standards. Here is a revised version of the code that addresses the issue by ensuring that interactive elements (in this case, those with a role of "tab") are not nested within each other. Instead, they should be siblings to each other and properly structured within a container that defines their group role, for example, `tablist` for tabs. ```html
Tab 1
Tab 2
Tab 3
Tab 4
``` Key Corrections and Considerations: 1. **Use of `role="tablist"`**: The `div` that wraps all tabs acts as the container for the tabs and is given the `role` of `tablist`. This semantic role indicates that it contains elements with a role of `tab`, making it clearer for assistive technologies. 2. **Siblings, Not Nested**: Each tab is now a sibling of the other tabs, not nested within one another, adhering to the principle of not nesting interactive controls. 3. **Tab Index and Aria Attributes**: I added `tabindex` and appropriate ARIA (`aria-selected`, `aria-controls`) attributes to further enhance accessibility. The `tabindex="0"` makes the first tab navigable via keyboard (it's the default active tab), while `tabindex="-1"` ensures the others are focusable programmatically but not via keyboard navigation until they become active. The `aria-selected="true"` attribute is used to indicate the currently active tab, and `aria-controls` points to the ID of the tab panel that the tab controls (you will need to ensure corresponding panels exist with matching IDs). 4. **ARIA Labels and Roles**: Consider adding appropriate `aria-label` or `aria-labelledby` attributes to the `tablist` and each `tab` to ensure each tab and the container is properly described for users of assistive technologies. The example includes an `aria-label` for the `tablist`. Be sure to update the IDs (`panel1`, `panel2`, etc.) to match the actual IDs of the panels that each tab is supposed to control, and remember to set the correct `aria-selected`, `tabindex`, and `aria-controls` values based on the interaction logic. This setup provides a foundation for enhancing accessibility while maintaining functionality.

Given that this is an advertisement iframe, a more suitable role could either be removed (because `iframe` elements do not necessarily require a role for assistive technologies to understand them), or if we want to be explicit about its content being an advertisement, we could possibly use `role="advertisement"`, although this role is not officially recognized in ARIA 1.1.

A better approach to improve accessibility might involve ensuring that the iframe or the content it refers to is properly described and labeled for assistive technologies, rather than focusing on the ARIA role. For an advertisement, it could be more about providing a clear label (via `aria-label` or `title` attribute already in place) that it is an advertisement. Since `role="advertisement"` is not a standard role, we may not change the role but can ensure the `title` attribute clearly explains the content. The `title` does this, but depending on context, more descriptive text might be advised if it doesn't interfere with the user experience.

However, to address the accessibility issue related to the ARIA role being appropriate for the element, you need to ensure that the role assigned to the `<iframe>` is suitable and accurately reflects the iframe's purpose or functionality.

The `role="region"` given to the iframe is meant to indicate a section of content that is sufficiently important that users will likely want to be able to navigate to it. While this can be appropriate in some cases, assigning a more specific role can improve the experience for users of assistive technologies if it better reflects the content's purpose. Since this iframe is specifically for advertisements, there isn't a more specific role designed for advertising content, but it's crucial to ensure that the role used does not mislead or confuse users about the content's nature.

Based on the given scenario, the role "region" could be seen as appropriate because the content is an advertisement that is a distinct section of the page, and with the `aria-label` attribute provided, it offers a clear description of the region's purpose. However, it's also important to ensure that when using `role="region"`, the element should have an accessible name, which in this case, is provided by `aria-label="Advertisement"`.

Still, it’s essential to ensure the content follows other accessibility best practices, like providing meaningful alternative content for users who cannot access iframes.

  name="" 
  scrolling="no" 
  marginwidth="0"

This can be achieved by providing unique labels via `aria-label` or `aria-labelledby`.

If you have more than one gallery or navigation landmark, you should continue to give them unique labels like "Gallery 1", "Gallery 2", "Secondary Navigation", etc., depending on their content and context within your webpage.

prompts_baseline_one: Given the following source code "<button><svg aria-hidden="true" class="nova-legacy-e-icon nova-legacy-e-icon--size-s nova-legacy-e-icon--theme-bare nova-legacy-e-icon--color-grey nova-legacy-e-icon--luminosity-medium"><use xlink:href="/m/4151594225983810/images/icons/nova/icon-stack-s.svg#magnifier-s"></use></svg></button>", can you fix the accessibility issue related to the success criteria: ( Buttons must have discernible text ) according to WCAG 2.1?
responses_baseline_one:
Yes, to address the accessibility issue in the provided button code according to the Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG) 2.1 success criterion related to "Buttons must have discernible text", we need to ensure that screen readers and other assistive technologies can understand the button's purpose. This criterion ensures that all users, including those with visual impairments, can navigate and interact with web content. Since the button contains an SVG image with an icon and does not include any text, it is not accessible by default. We can fix this by adding an `aria-label` attribute to the button with a descriptive text value that indicates the button's purpose or function. Here's the corrected code:

```html
<button aria-label="Search">
  <svg aria-hidden="true" class="nova-legacy-e-icon nova-legacy-e-icon--size-s nova-legacy-e-icon--theme-bare nova-legacy-e-icon--color-grey nova-legacy-e-icon--luminosity-medium">
    <use xlink:href="/m/4151594225983810/images/icons/nova/icon-stack-s.svg#magnifier-s"></use>
  </svg>
</button>
```

In this correction:
- I added `aria-label="Search"` to the `<button>` element. This provides assistive technologies with a text label that describes the button's purpose, which is to initiate a search action in this case.
- I kept `aria-hidden="true"` for the SVG to ensure that the SVG icon is hidden from screen readers, as its appearance is purely decorative relative to the button's function, which we've now described with `aria-label`.

With these changes, the button now complies with the WCAG 2.1 success criteria for providing discernible text for interactive elements, making the content more accessible to users relying on screen readers and other assistive technologies.

prompts_baseline_one:
Given the following source code "Join for free Engineering Mathematics Biology Computer Science Climate Change Medicine Physics Social Science Astrophysics Chemistry Join for free Find out more Find out more About us News Careers Help Center Terms Privacy Copyright Imprint Researchers Q&A Publications Jobs Advertising Recruiting
© 2008-2023 ResearchGate GmbH. All rights reserved.
", can you fix the accessibility issue related to the success criteria: ( Elements must meet minimum color contrast ratio thresholds ) according to WCAG 2.1?
responses_baseline_one:
To address accessibility issues related to color contrast according to the WCAG 2.1 guidelines, we would need access to CSS or style attributes that are currently applied to these HTML elements. The guidelines suggest that text and interactive elements should have a color contrast ratio of at least 4.5:1 for normal text and 3:1 for large text (18pt or 14pt bold) against their background colors to ensure that users with visual impairments can read the content.

Since the provided source code does not include color information, I will provide a hypothetical CSS fix assuming default color values that commonly cause contrast issues.

**Hypothetical Original CSS (Assumed Problematic):**
```css
.index-header__sign-up, .index-connect__keyword-name, .index-signup__join-btn-label, .index-footer__btn-label, span {
    color: #757575; /* Light grey text, often not enough contrast against light backgrounds */
    background-color: #FFF; /* White background */
}

.index-footer__base-copyright {
    color: #999999; /* Even lighter grey, potentially problematic */
    background-color: #FFF; /* White background */
}
```

**CSS Fix:**
To address the contrast issue, change the text colors to ensure they meet or exceed the minimum contrast ratio required by WCAG 2.1.

```css
/* Revised CSS to improve contrast */
.index-header__sign-up, .index-connect__keyword-name, .index-signup__join-btn-label, .index-footer__btn-label, span {
    color: #000000; /* Changed to black for higher contrast */
    background-color: #FFF; /* Keeping the white background */
}

.index-footer__base-copyright {
    color: #4F4F4F; /* Darker grey to improve contrast */
    background-color: #FFF; /* White background */
}
```

**Additional Considerations:**
- If any of these elements (particularly links or buttons) have states (like hover or focus), ensure those states also meet the contrast requirements.
- The background color and text color mentioned in the CSS fixes are hypothetical and should be adjusted based on the actual backgrounds and design requirements of your web page.
- Tools like the WebAIM Contrast Checker can help validate color contrast ratios to ensure they meet WCAG 2.1 standards.

Remember, addressing accessibility concerns isn't just about meeting technical specifications; it's about ensuring that the content is universally accessible and providing an equitable user experience.

prompts_baseline_one: Given the following source code "<html lang="en" class="js-focus-visible" data-js-focus-visible="">", can you fix the accessibility issue related to the success criteria: ( Document should have one main landmark ) according to WCAG 2.1?
responses_baseline_one:
Yes, the given source code snippet lacks the main content landmark, which is crucial for accessibility, especially for screen readers and other assistive technologies. To adhere to WCAG 2.1, specifically the success criteria regarding the presence of a single main landmark, you should encapsulate the primary content of the web page within `<main>` tags. This element serves as the primary landmark of the document, making navigation and comprehension much easier for users relying on assistive technologies.

Here's how you could adjust the source code to improve its accessibility:

```html
<html lang="en" class="js-focus-visible" data-js-focus-visible="">
<head>
  <!-- Your head content like meta tags, title, link to CSS files go here -->
</head>
<body>
  <!-- Any header, navigation, or similar content goes here -->
  
  <!-- Main landmark starts here -->
  <main>
    <!-- Primary content of your web page goes here -->
  </main>
  <!-- Main landmark ends here -->

  <!-- Any footer, scripts, or additional content goes below -->
</body>
</html>
```

By wrapping the central content of your page within the `<main>` tags, you establish a clear main landmark. Remember, it's best practice to ensure there is only one `<main>` landmark per page. This approach directly addresses the accessibility issue related to the "Document should have one main landmark" criterion under WCAG 2.1, making your web content more accessible to users with disabilities.
